Top-tier weapon is a weapon that can drastically, single-handedly change the course of a fight or win it altogether. Classic examples r Flail (unblockable, high dmg), Whip (6th sense to the extreme & multihit) and Trombone (high everything).


Now, u tell us, mister fancy Abel, what's so special about Trident?
In most cases, it doesn't drastically affect a fight to the same degree as the above. U must have 6th-Sense so it becomes increasingly hard to attack, but it's still low-multi, slow and easily blockable.

[1214962]

I've had ballet shoes on both my backup and mid level brutes. Ballet shoes (and thief) are better on backup brutes.

However, if you've taken Ballet Shoes already it isn't the end of the world. You may not block or dodge much and if a flail vulnerable opponent also has first strike, it provides a chance of avoiding a big heavy weapon hit or a sabotage. Consider it a forking point. More skills leads to more "choices" in future like +3 speed or +2 endurance and +1 speed, but sometimes a poorer skill that doesn't make your brute worse still opens up a nice path.

Survival is better than ballet shoes since it only takes effect when you are hit.

On october 24, 2013
flojo3
45424And the higher level you are, the more chance you'll be offered stats.

There are 2 ways I think that you can look at that. The first one that's being suggested in this thread is that the more skills you take, the lower your chance is of getting one at every subsequent level.


It's also a possibility that each skill/weapon has a certain chance of being an option, for example let's say immortality has a 1% and broadsword has a 5% chance. That would mean every time you get a skill/wep the chance of getting any skill/wep is lowered, but the chance of getting a particular one is the same.


But at the end of the day no one really knows how the system works and everything is just an assumption.


Maybe one of these theories would be possible to prove if lot's of high lvl brutes would provide their skill trees so we could look at correlations and other things

MrPapaya

SMILES You make a good point about Ballet Shoes avoiding a hit that may have been avoided anyways. It's a +1 reason to pass the skill if ur brute has good dodging abilities.


As far as Survival goes, ur statement is true but assumes actually reaching the end of the fight. Ur brute may never lose all his health (-1), and thus not use Survival at all


45424And the higher level you are, the more chance you'll be offered stats.

As Flojo said, this is entirely an assumption. What lends it seeming credence is the fact that the more skills/weapons u have, the more % of being offered the same skills/weapons u already have. So, u see +2/+1 stats more frequently, but it's just an indirect consequence.


grinicIt depends on the situation. If the opponent has determination he will hit you with full damage even if you have BS, while if you have survival he needs to hit you twice.

If u get multi-hit by > ur health, Ballet Shoes will dodge the first blow and u will die if u get hit. Survival will let u survive the first hit and then u will die once hit. The difference is that by then u may have lost ur shield/weapon due to Sabotage/Shock, while u'd still have them on with Ballet Shoes.

in this early level I would decline vitality first because you'll get in the next few levels another stat booster offered and if HS and FA - take it.
but thats just my way to do decide. because you can easily balance the low hp with just one skill -> resistant but low str or low agi is not so easily balanced.
